author: gwintery
content: Does running an eth2 node help with decentralization even if you're not validating? Is there anywhere I can read up on the economic disincentives that would discourage/prevent big validators from forming a malicious cartel and slash smaller honest validators? (Sorry if my understanding of this is totally off base)

author: edson.eth
content: I think the case where just running a validator would improve decentralization is access to the API, right? Instead of relying on something like Infura.

author: gwintery
content: Right now the top 20 unique address accounts for more than 50% of validator count. Not sure if some of these address are also owned by the same person but just spread out.

author: pieterastra
content:
what impact will a much higher ETH price have on decentralization, do you think?
Will people still be comfortable running and securing a validator from home when 6 figures or more are at stake?

The same applies to having funds on a hardware wallet to some extent, I guess

author: benjaminion
content: A small portion (1/512th) of the balance of a slashed validator goes to the block proposer (the whistle blower gets nothing in Phase 0). The slashed amount is burned, as are all penalties.
